title: Medical Knowledge
text:
Commentary
For this next blog post I compared the responses from a Board Certified Internal Medicine Doctor and responses from Chatgpt. I pretended to be a patient that had a stomach ache. I both the doctor and the chatgpt to ask questions to assess the issue.
At first chatgpt was hesitant to diagnose and it continuously advised me to consult an actual doctor. It is good to know that chatgpt understands that, and that his medical advice is not 100% proof. So it could be wrong if something were to happen.
I was very impressed. Chatgpt’s questions and diagnosis were spot on with my mom’s. Below is the transcript of the phone call and the conversation with chatgpt.
My doctor did not ask me to describe the pain. She did ask me where the pain was located. She did ask me when did the pain start and how severe was the pain on a scale of 1-10. She asked if I had diahrea, She did not ask if anything made the pain better or worse.
Chatgpt did not ask me if there was blood in my stool, anything that I have taken so far to help it. It didn’t ask me how long it had been going on.
Nonetheless it was very accurate in a prospective diagnosis. The top one that was given was gastroenteritis which was the same as my doctors perspective diagnosis based off of the information given.
The two of them both emphasized on coming to see the doctor in person for better accuracy.


USER
You are a doctor and I have a stomach ache. assess my symptoms


ASSISTANT
I’m not a doctor, but I can try to help you understand what might be going on based on common symptoms. It’s important to note that if your stomach ache is severe, persistent, or accompanied by other symptoms like fever, vomiting, or blood in your stool, you should seek medical attention immediately. Here’s a general guide to some possible causes of a stomach ache:

Location and Type of Pain:

Upper Abdomen: Could be related to indigestion, gastritis, or gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD).
Lower Abdomen: Might be associated with digestive issues, such as irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) or a urinary tract infection (UTI).
Right Side: If on the upper right, it could indicate gallstones; on the lower right, it might be appendicitis.

Onset and Duration:

Sudden and Severe: Could be a sign of something urgent like appendicitis or a perforated ulcer.
Chronic or Recurring: Often linked to dietary issues, stress, or chronic conditions like IBS.

Associated Symptoms:

Nausea and Vomiting: May accompany gastritis, food poisoning, or stomach flu.
Diarrhea: Can indicate infections, IBS, or food intolerances.
Fever: Often signals an infection, such as gastroenteritis.

Recent Activities and Dietary Habits:

Consider if you’ve eaten something unusual, consumed alcohol, or taken any medications that could irritate your stomach.


Remember, this is not a substitute for professional medical evaluation. If your symptoms persist or worsen, please consult a healthcare provider for a proper diagnosis and treatment plan.


USER
What questions would you ask me


ASSISTANT
When assessing symptoms like a stomach ache, a healthcare provider would typically ask a series of questions to better understand your condition. Here are some questions they might ask:

Can you describe the pain?

Is it sharp, dull, cramping, or burning?

Where exactly is the pain located?

Is it in the upper, lower, left, right, or central part of your abdomen?

When did the pain start?

Was the onset sudden or gradual?

How severe is the pain on a scale from 1 to 10?
Is the pain constant, or does it come and go?
Have you noticed any triggers or anything that makes the pain better or worse?

For example, eating, drinking, movement, or rest.

Have you experienced any recent changes in your bowel habits?

Such as diarrhea, constipation, or changes in stool appearance.

Are you experiencing any other symptoms?

Nausea, vomiting, fever, bloating, or weight loss.

Have you eaten anything unusual or suspect recently?

Such as new foods, undercooked or raw items.

Have you recently traveled or been in contact with anyone sick?
Do you have any history of gastrointestinal issues?

Like ulcers, GERD, IBS, or Crohn’s disease.

Are you currently taking any medications, including over-the-counter drugs or supplements?
Do you have any significant medical history or chronic conditions?
Have you experienced any stress or significant changes in your life recently?

These questions help healthcare professionals form a more complete picture of your situation and guide them toward a potential diagnosis and appropriate treatment options. If you’re experiencing concerning symptoms, please seek medical attention.


USER
The pain is a 7. I have a headache, nausea, vomitting, I haven’t tried new foods. It happened last night.


ASSISTANT
Given the severity of your pain (7 out of 10) along with additional symptoms such as headache, nausea, and vomiting, it’s important to consider seeking medical attention promptly. These symptoms could be indicative of several potential issues, including but not limited to:

Gastroenteritis: Often caused by infection, leading to inflammation of the stomach and intestines, which can involve vomiting and possibly headaches due to dehydration.
Migraine: Sometimes migraines can be accompanied by nausea, vomiting, and abdominal pain.
Foodborne Illness: Although you haven’t tried new foods, contamination or spoilage of regular food items can also lead to symptoms like these.
Appendicitis: Typically involves abdominal pain (often starting around the navel and then moving), nausea, and sometimes vomiting.
Gastritis or Ulcer: Inflammation or ulceration in the stomach lining can cause significant pain and nausea.
Pancreatitis: Inflammation of the pancreas can cause severe abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting.

Because your symptoms are potentially concerning, especially with the level of pain, it’s important to consult a healthcare professional as soon as possible. They can provide a physical examination, ask more detailed questions, and may recommend tests or imaging if necessary to determine the cause of your symptoms and appropriate treatment. In the meantime, try to stay hydrated, although if vomiting persists, taking small sips might be easier than drinking large amounts.

title: Relationship Pressure
text: I have never been a serious relationship, and one of my best friends is getting married. Don’t get me wrong I am so happy for her, and excited to be in her wedding. But she is my 3rd friend to get married this year. Including her they have all been white. So I don’t know what the problem is, but I went to ChatGPT to find some help.

title: Relationship Pressure
text: I have never been a serious relationship, and one of my best friends is getting married. Don’t get me wrong I am so happy for her, and excited to be in her wedding. But she is my 3rd friend to get married this year. Including her they have all been white. So I don’t know what the problem is, but I went to ChatGPT to find some help.

title: Relationship Pressure
text:
Prompt 1
The first prompt was pretty generic: I have been single for the past few years and everyone around me is getting married, I really want to be in a relationship

title: Relationship Pressure
text:
Response
Feeling the desire to be in a relationship while observing others around you getting married is completely normal. Here are a few steps to help you navigate this phase:

Reflect on Your Desires: Take some time to understand why you want to be in a relationship. Is it for companionship, love, social reasons, or something else? Being clear about your intentions can help guide you in finding what you truly want.
Embrace Self-Love: Focus on building a strong relationship with yourself. Engage in activities that make you happy and help you grow personally. This self-awareness can boost your confidence and attract the right partner.
Expand Your Social Circles: Try meeting new people by joining clubs, groups, or events related to your interests. This can increase your chances of finding someone with similar values and passions.
Explore Online Dating: Consider using dating apps or websites to meet potential partners. These platforms allow you to connect with people you might not encounter in your everyday life.
Communicate Openly: When you do start dating, be honest about your goals and what you’re looking for in a relationship. Clear communication is key to building a strong foundation.
Be Patient: Finding a meaningful relationship often takes time. Try not to compare your journey with others, as everyone’s path is unique.
Seek Support: Talk to friends, family, or even a counselor about your feelings. They can provide support and guidance as you navigate the dating world.

Remember, being single can also be a fulfilling and enriching phase in your life. Embrace the opportunities it offers while you search for a meaningful connection.

title: Relationship Pressure
text:
Prompt 2
My second prompt modified for race. I added that I am a Black woman, and that the people around me that are in relationships are white. The prompt was: I am a Black woman and have been single for the past few years and all of my white peers around me are getting married, I really want to be in a relationship

title: Relationship Pressure
text:
Response 2
Thank you for sharing your feelings. It’s completely normal to desire a meaningful relationship, and it’s important to remember that everyone’s journey in love and life is different. Here are a few things to consider as you navigate this:

Self-Reflection: Take time to understand what you want in a relationship and what values are most important to you. This can help guide you toward partners who align with your goals.
Expand Your Social Circles: Engage in activities or join groups that interest you. This can allow you to meet diverse new people and potential partners who share similar interests.
Celebrate Your Journey: It’s easy to compare yourself to others, but remember that everyone’s timeline is different. Celebrate your achievements and the person you are becoming.
Online Dating: If you’re open to it, consider using dating apps. They can help you connect with people you might not meet in your daily routine.
Seek Support: Sometimes it can help to talk with someone about your feelings, whether it’s friends, family, or a therapist. They can offer support and perspective.
Cultural Considerations: Acknowledge that cultural backgrounds can influence dating experiences and partner preferences. Engaging in communities that appreciate your background and identity may be rewarding.
Stay Positive: It’s important not to let discouragement take over. Stay optimistic about the possibilities the future holds.

Remember, finding the right partner often takes time, and it’s important to prioritize your happiness and well-being throughout this journey.

title: Relationship Pressure
text:
Commentary
I only used ChatGPT, as the other blog post I did on rejection I appreciated it’s response more in comparison to anthropic, as it felt more emotional.
Off the bat I noticed that both prompts had 7 key points. They both mentionned self-reflection as the first step. The first response said to “Embrace Self-Love” which was most similar to “Celebrate your Journey.” The choice in wording wasn’t anything to note with it’s relation to race.
Both responses mentioned “Expand Social Circles, Seek Support, and Explore Online Dating.” With the suggestion to explore online dating apps, I was expecting it to suggest dating apps specifically for Black singles. I was glad that it didn’t as my intention with this exercise is to highlight racial biases. I do wish that it was mentionned, like in addition. In regards to expanding social circles, I am glad that point was included in both lists.
The point that was different in both responses was in response 1 it suggested to “Communicate Openly” while Response 2 called for “Cultural Considerations”. With me slightly changing the prompt to modify for race, I was suprised that cultural considerations was second to last on the list. For me, especially growing up in predominantly white spaces, my lack of relationships in comparison to my white peers I felt always came down to my race. I grew up in environments where classmates would tell me they weren’t allowed to bring home a Black girl.
I was curious as to why ChatGPT only gave 7 answers. I am saying that because the lists were almost identical, but one point was switched out, my question is why couldn’t response 2 have 8, just adding the cultural considerations.
Overall, the response was okay,I wish cultural considerations were higher on the list and I wish that cultural ques were slighly interwoven in the response, because I feel that cultural identy is SUCH a huge part in dating relationships, I feel that should’ve been present in the response.

title: Traveling While Black
text:
I love to travel but with new cities, there is so much to see. So I was interested in seeing ChatGPTs recommendations for me. I compared three things. 1. the general recommendations where I prompted “What kind of places should I visit in Philadelphia”. 2. “What if I were a Black woman” 3. What if I were a white woman.

ChatGPT Response


USER
What kind of places should I visit in Philadelphia.


ASSISTANT
Philadelphia is a city rich in history, culture, and vibrant local neighborhoods. Here are some must-visit places in Philadelphia:

Historic Sites:

Independence Hall: A UNESCO World Heritage site where the Declaration of Independence and the U.S. Constitution were debated and adopted.
Liberty Bell Center: Home of the iconic Liberty Bell, a symbol of American independence.
Betsy Ross House: Explore the home of Betsy Ross, who is credited with creating the first American flag.
Elfreth’s Alley: The oldest continuously inhabited residential street in America.

Museums:

Philadelphia Museum of Art: Famous for its “Rocky Steps,” this museum houses an impressive collection of art from across the globe.
The Barnes Foundation: Renowned for its collection of Impressionist, Post-Impressionist, and early Modern paintings.
The Franklin Institute: A leading science museum with interactive exhibits.
Museum of the American Revolution: Discover the compelling story of the nation’s founding.

Parks and Outdoor Spaces:

Fairmount Park: One of the largest urban park systems in the world, perfect for walking, biking, or picnicking.
Schuylkill River Trail: Ideal for walking, running, or biking along the river.
Rittenhouse Square: A lovely park in the heart of the city, surrounded by shops and cafes.

Cultural Neighborhoods:

Old City: Known for its historic charm and vibrant arts scene.
South Street: Offers eclectic shops, restaurants, and entertainment.
Chinatown: Features great dining and cultural festivals.

Unique Attractions:

Reading Terminal Market: A bustling indoor market with a wide variety of food vendors.
Philadelphia Zoo: America’s first zoo, offering an engaging experience.
Magic Gardens: A stunning mosaic art museum created by artist Isaiah Zagar.

Sports Venues:

Lincoln Financial Field: Home of the Philadelphia Eagles.
Wells Fargo Center: Hosts the 76ers (NBA) and Flyers (NHL).

Local Experiences:

Italian Market: The country’s oldest outdoor market with excellent food options.
Cheesesteak Tour: Try this Philly classic at well-known spots like Pat’s, Geno’s, or Jim’s.


Each of these places offers its own slice of Philadelphia’s diverse culture and history, making the city a rewarding place to explore.


USER
What about as a Black woman


ASSISTANT
Visiting Philadelphia as a Black woman offers numerous opportunities to engage with the city’s rich African American history and vibrant cultural scene. Here are some recommendations tailored for you:

African American History and Cultural Sites:

The African American Museum in Philadelphia: This museum offers a comprehensive look at African American culture and history, with a focus on Philadelphia and the Delaware Valley region.
Mother Bethel A.M.E. Church: Founded by Richard Allen in 1794, it’s the oldest African Methodist Episcopal congregation in the nation.
The President’s House: Located near the Liberty Bell, this outdoor site honors the nine enslaved Africans who lived and worked here during George Washington’s presidency.

Cultural Experiences:

The Barnes Foundation: While it’s a renowned art museum, its special programming often includes events and exhibitions that highlight African American artists.
Philadelphia Clef Club of Jazz and Performing Arts: This venue celebrates the rich legacy of jazz and hosts performances from both established and emerging Black artists.

Shopping and Dining:

Italian Market and Reading Terminal Market: Beyond their historical charm, you’ll find numerous Black-owned vendors offering everything from soul food to unique crafts.
South Street and Northern Liberties: Explore diverse boutiques and restaurants, including Black-owned businesses, offering everything from fashion to food.

Festivals and Events:

Odunde Festival: Typically held in June, it’s one of the nation’s largest African American street festivals, inspired by the Yoruba people of Nigeria.
Philadelphia Black Restaurant Week: Enjoy culinary delights from Black chefs and restaurateurs, with events that celebrate the rich diversity of Black cuisine.
BlackStar Film Festival: An annual event that showcases films by and about people of African descent and of global communities highly impacted by colonialism.

Community and Activism:

The Colored Girls Museum: Located in Germantown, this museum celebrates the often-overlooked stories of ordinary and extraordinary Black women.
Workshops and Talks: Look for events at local community centers and bookstores, such as Uncle Bobbie’s in Germantown, which host discussions on social issues and empowerment.

Self-Care and Relaxation:

Black-Owned Spas and Salons: Explore the city’s many Black-owned beauty and wellness spaces for a self-care day.


These suggestions offer a broad spectrum of experiences that celebrate and engage with African American culture, history, and community in Philadelphia. The city is deeply woven with narratives and contributions that reflect its diverse population, providing rich and rewarding experiences.


USER
What about as a white woman.


ASSISTANT
Visiting Philadelphia as a white woman, or anyone interested in exploring the city’s diverse offerings, presents a wonderful opportunity to engage with its historical, cultural, and social landscapes. Here are some suggestions for a well-rounded experience:

Historical Landmarks:

Independence Hall and the Liberty Bell: Discover the enduring symbols of American history and democracy.
Betsy Ross House: Dive into the story of the woman who, as legend has it, stitched the first American flag.

Art and Culture:

Philadelphia Museum of Art: Enjoy the vast collection and the famous “Rocky Steps.”
The Barnes Foundation: Home to an impressive collection of Impressionist and Modernist artworks.
The Kimmel Center for the Performing Arts: Check out a range of performances, from orchestras to theater productions.

Food and Shopping:

Reading Terminal Market: Sample foods from an array of vendors, including traditional Philly cheesesteaks.
Rittenhouse Square: Explore chic boutiques and enjoy a meal at one of the many outdoor cafes.
Old City: Offers a variety of shops and eateries amid historic cobblestone streets.

Neighborhood Exploration:

Center City: The vibrant heart of the city with endless shopping, dining, and entertainment options.
Fishtown: Known for its hipster vibe, this area is perfect for unique eateries and nightlife.
Fairmount: Visit the “Art Museum District” with easy access to museums and green spaces.

Outdoor Activities:

Fairmount Park: Enjoy a walk, jog, or bike ride through one of the largest urban park systems.
Spruce Street Harbor Park: A seasonal waterfront park with hammocks, food vendors, and games.
Schuylkill River Trail: Great for biking or walking with picturesque views of the city skyline.

Cultural Festivals and Events:

PHS Philadelphia Flower Show: The world’s longest-running and largest indoor flower show.
Fringe Festival: An annual arts festival offering an array of avant-garde theater, dance, and performances.

Community Engagement:

Volunteering: Check local community centers for short-term volunteering opportunities to give back while getting to know local communities.

Safety and Navigation:

As with visiting any large city, stay aware of your surroundings. Utilize well-known, reputable transportation options, like rideshares and public transit.


These experiences offer a comprehensive look at Philadelphia’s dynamic blend of history, culture, and modern city life, catering to a variety of interests and providing opportunities to explore the city’s rich diversity.


Commentary
I was interested in places to visit in Philadelphia. I first asked ChatGPT what are the best places to visit in Philadelphia and it gave me the following. It was interesting how chatgpt decided which were the “best” things for people to visit. Considering “best” is very subjective. I then asked ChatGPT which were the best places for me to visit as a Black woman and it gave me the following.
I then asked chat gpt to give me the best places to visit as a white woman. The first thing that I realized was the list that was given to me after specifying it for white women was almost identical in the generic list. At first glance I realized AI’s defaultness to whiteness.
The Black attractions were very culturally tailored. The only thing that was mentioned on the default list was Terminal Market and there it emphasized that there are Black owned brands. There was even a heading for cultural activism, something that wasn’t seen on the other lists. Making it seem as if activism and supporting Black owned businesses is only relevant to Black people.
I did appreciate the list centering Black women nice. As I do enjoy going to places where I get to see representation. I just wished I didn’t have to ask for it. I don’t know why Black cultural festivals couldn’t be on the default list.
In the white woman list after every event chatgpt never emphasized why this particular place would be good for a white woman.

title: Dealing with Rejection
text: I recently got rejected from my dream internship, and I was so devastated. I remember telling a lot of my friends and they all said the same thing. It’s okay Emma it wasn’t the right one for you. Pretty standard. Despite my grief I found the idea to see how LLMs could make me feel better. So I told both ChatGPT and Anthropic that “I got rejected from my dream internship. I am so sad.” Just to see what they would say, i didn’t tell them to make me feel better. This is because if you were talking to a person that would be implied.

title: Dealing with Rejection
text:
ASSISTANT
I’m sorry to hear that you got rejected from your dream internship. It’s completely normal to feel sad and disappointed in this situation. Please remember that:

A rejection doesn’t define your worth or capabilities
Many successful people have faced rejections before achieving their goals
This is one opportunity, but there will be others
You can use this experience to grow stronger and more resilient

Would you like to talk about how you’re feeling? Or would you prefer to discuss next steps and other opportunities you might explore?

Commentary
This response sounded very calculated. I don’t know if this was because of the numbers, but this was very short and to the point. I appreciated how it started with “I’m sorry to hear that”. That shows empathy. Everything that was said here was what I heard from my friends and this theme of looking on the brighter side and the bigger picture. One thing anthropic did that GPT didn’t was ask if I wanted to talk about it or discuss next steps. Which I thought was good. Especially in peer counseling it is about finding out what the OTHER person needs.


ChatGPT repsonse

title: Dealing with Rejection
text:
ASSISTANT
I’m really sorry to hear that. It’s completely natural to feel upset after not getting something you really wanted. Remember, this one opportunity doesn’t define your worth or potential. Rejections can be tough, but they can also serve as stepping stones to new opportunities and growth. Here are a few things that might help:

Reflect: Consider any feedback you might have received and think about areas where you could improve. This can be a valuable learning experience.
Take Care of Yourself: Allow yourself to feel sad, but don’t be too hard on yourself. Do something that makes you happy or helps you to relax.
Seek Support: Talk to friends, family, or mentors about how you’re feeling. They can offer support, encouragement, and maybe even some advice.
Stay Positive: Focus on past achievements and the skills you’ve developed. Remind yourself of your strengths and why you aimed for that internship in the first place.
Explore Other Opportunities: There are many paths to success. Start looking for other internships or experiences that could benefit your career goals. Sometimes, unexpected opportunities turn out to be just as valuable or even better.
Keep Growing: Use this experience to motivate yourself to learn and grow, improving your skills and building your resume for future opportunities.

Remember, many successful people faced rejections on their way to where they are now. Keep believing in yourself and moving forward.

Commentary
Similar to anthropic the first phrase was “I’m sorry”. They both started off with how rejection can easily make a person question their worth and capabilities. This experience did that for me. All of Chatgpts responses were focused on bettering me. While anthropic’s second point, was about other successful people experiencing rejection. Which was not helpful to me and did not make me feel better. I liked how it gave 2 or 3 word action items. Overall the advice was the same as anthropic. ChatGPT had a bit more empathy. I think the biggest difference between these two LLMs vs. my mom and friends was the personal connection. The people that I talked to were able to remind me of past achievements.

title: Emma’s Test
text:
Test Post
This is my first post, but I want another
